type_set(2)={bigger }

f(equal,bigger)=x

f(unequal,bigger)=y

X={x,y}

x=(a,b) where |a|=|b|

y=(a,b) where |a|<|b|

x and y are basically allocation vector.|p| denotes the size of  cake piece p.

history.subject: Discussion 6
history.content: Can you come up with dominant strategy/Bayesian solutions for a cake cutting problem with three kids.

child.subject:
The procedure is called Banach-knaster protocol.

The following is done 3 times:
1 A player cuts a piece which they consider to be of size 1/3.
2 Every other player can "trim it" to what they consider 1/3 or else they can decide to pass.
3 Last player to cut the piece, keeps it, the procedure continues with the remaining players.
This is an outline of the procedure.
More ideas on fair division

The Dubins-Spanier procedure is also an alternative way.

Dubins and Spanier (1961) proposed an alternative proportional procedure for arbitrary n. It produces contiguous slices (and hence uses a minimal number of cuts), but it is not discrete anymore and it requires the active help of a referee.
(1) A referee moves a knife slowly across the cake, from left to right. Any player may shout “stop” at any time. Whoever does so receives the piece to the left of the knife.

(2) When a piece has been cut off, we continue with the remaining n−1 players, until just one player is left (who takes the rest).

Check the attached doc (comsoccakes.pdf) for more details.

1st child will be asked to cut cake in 3 pieces. After cutting is over 2nd and 3rd child (or  3rd and 2nd child ) child will choose their pieces.and 1st child will get the last left over piece.Now 2nd and 3rd child will always leave the smallest piece for 1st child.So,it's  better for the first child to maximize the size of the smallest piece. This problem has only solution to cut the cake into 3 equal pieces.

history.subject: DSIC - clarification
history.content:
Chapter 17, page 248:

To explain the SCF given by  $$f(a_1,a_2) = x; f(a_1,b_2) = x$$ is DSIC, the following argument is presented.

If $$\theta_2 = a_2$$ and player 2 reports as $$a_2$$, the outcome is $$x$$. If he misreports as $$b_2$$, then again the outcome is $$x$$. Hence there is no incentive for player 2 to misreport.

But, from the utility function: $$u_2(x,a_2) < u_2(x,b_2)$$

This means that player 2 would always report $$b_2$$ as his type whenever the SCF outcome is $$x$$, even his true type is $$a_2$$.

Then how is this DSIC?

history.subject: DSIC - clarification
history.content:
Chapter 17, page 248:

To explain the SCF given by  $$f(a_1,a_2) = x; f(a_1,b_2) = x$$ is DSIC, the following argument is presented.

If $$\theta_2 = a_2$$ and player 2 reports as $$a_2$$, the outcome is $$x$$. If he misreports as $$b_2$$, then again the outcome is $$x$$. Hence there is no incentive for player 2 to misreport.

But, from the utility function:

$$u_2(x,a_2) < u_2(x,b_2)$$

This means that player 2 would always report $$b_2$$ as his type whenever the SCF outcome is $$x$$, even his true type is $$a_2$$.

Then how is this DSIC?

child.subject: the utility is always calculated with respect to the true type of the player. so if the player reports b_2 when his true type is a_2, then the outcome will be x according to the SCF and  the utility the player derives is going to be u_2(x, a_2)  and not u_2(x,b_2). Similar reasoning  holds when the true type of the player is b_2 but the player reports a_2.
Thanks, got it.

history.content:
Players equilibrium strategy has to be weakly dominant pure strategy in induced game for DSIC. Here the equilibrium strategy for pl 2 is vwdse. As strict inrquality do not hold in any of alternatives, while players 1s notion of BIC snd DSIC is same, it is a dominant strategy for player 1 to bid his true valuation.

Hence player 1 forces it to be DSIC.

history.subject: EPE and Pareto optimality
history.content:
A note on EPE and P.O.

If we need to show that an SCF is EPE , we need to check for all type profiles  whether f($$\Theta $$)  is P.O.

Now to prove f($$\Theta $$) is P.O. , for each outcome $$x \epsilon X \setminus f(\Theta )$$, just find one player for which f($$\Theta $$) gives strictly better outcome than any outcome x s.t.   $$x \epsilon X \setminus f(\Theta )$$.

Then f($$\Theta $$) will be P.O. for that type profile.

Repeat this procedure for all type profiles to prove that this SCF is EPE.

history.subject: Incentive compatibility of an SCF. Q2 in Mid term-3
history.content:
Most of us had a doubt whether SCF which gives outcome x for all type profiles i.e. $$\Theta \epsilon \left \{ 0,1,2 \right \}$$ will be IC or not.
Since this is only one player game checking for DSIC will suffice.

Now if any SCF gives the same outcome on all type profiles , will always be I.C.

Reason : 

If a player report a type other than the true type , outcome given by the SCF will be same as in the case when player report true type.Hence player does not get better pay off by being untruthful .

So any SCF with same outcomes for all type profiles will be I.C.

history.subject: Bayesian IC
history.content: I was curious to know whether there are faster methods to check for BIC. If you know of any, kindly share them.

I think checking for BIC is similar to finding PSNE.

one can start by eliminating scf for which utility ,corresponding to outcome of scf ,of any user is strictly dominated by utility corresponding to non outcome but element of set X.

But one cant avoid checking for all users until you reach any of the cases.

1.for some user xpected utility corresponding to scf outcome is strictly less than that of outcome which is not the output of scf.

2.For all users NASC condition for BIC is satisfied

So we have to do necessary steps to check for BIC.

history.subject: Classify the auction correctly
history.content:
There are two types of auctions A and B explained as follows:

Auction A: Each bidder tries to outbid the other and bidders drop out one by one until only one bidder

is left. Assume that the ongoing price increases by an infinitesimal increment. The item is awarded

to the lone bidder left in the fray. This winner pays whatever is her latest bid.

Auction B: The auctioneer announces a high price first and waits to see if anyone is interested. If none is interested,

lowers the price by a small amount(assume infinitesimal amount) and waits to see if  anyone is interested. This is

repeated until someone expresses interest in buying it at that announced price. The winner will pay this current price.

(a)  Comment whether Auction A is equivalent to first price sealed bid auction.

(b)  Comment whether Auction A is equivalent to second price sealed bid auction.

(c)  Comment whether Auction B is equivalent to first price sealed bid auction.

(d)  Comment whether Auction B is equivalent to second price sealed bid auction.

Auction B is an example of Dutch auction which is not sealed bid like FPA or SPA.

 Auction B can be thought of as SPA because bidder dominant strategy is to stop when announcement falls below its own valuation. But winner do not pay second highest bid here as there is no such concept here.                        

        Cant say about auction A.its definately not SPA.

child.subject:
I am sorry , I am wrong in above answer.

Auction A is same as SPA and Auction B is same as FPA as stated in today's class.

Thanks

history.subject: Risk loving and risk neutral agents
history.content:
Risk loving agents tend to risk averseness if the involved payments are high.

example.

1. if player is asked to choose between gain of $100 with probability 0.9 and $90 for sure.

the risk loving player would choose option 1.

but if the same player is asked to

2.choose between $100000 with prob 0.9 and $90000 for sure, would choose second option.(with high probability)

 
Risk loving or risk averse nature of agents are not just natural tendencies towards risk but also a function of utilities involved.
    can players be made to be risk neutral by mechanism through choosing appropriate utilities, irrespective of their individual natural tendencies to take risks?

( for many such experiments on risk taking tendencies of people refer book ¨Choices Values and Frames" by Dan Kahnman and Amos Tversky.)

Players can be made to be risk neutral by mechanism through choosing appropriate utilities, irrespective of their individual natural tendencies to take risks. 

The explanation is as follows:-

After the exposure to Game Theory course, I feel that any player aware of game theory concepts would

make any decisions based on natural tendencies. The entire issue comes down to a single metric 

that is UTILITY (gain/profit). If there is a situation in real life and if we can somehow model a sound

mechanism design for this situation then, it is always advisable to follow the outcomes predicted by 

the use of mechanisms involved rather than play with natural tendencies. To summarise if we can prove

by use of mechanism that the utility involved is certain(profit) rather than have a probabilistic guess , it should 

be safe to follow the well established mechanisms rather than follow natural tendencies.

Players can be made to be risk neutral by mechanism through choosing appropriate utilities, irrespective of their individual natural tendencies to take risks. 

The explanation is as follows:-

After the exposure to Game Theory course, I feel that any player aware of game theory concepts would

make any decisions based on natural tendencies. The entire issue comes down to a single metric 

that is UTILITY (gain/profit). If there is a situation in real life and if we can somehow model a sound

mechanism design for this situation then, it is always advisable to follow the outcomes predicted by 

the use of mechanisms involved rather than play with natural tendencies. To summarise if we can prove

by use of mechanism that the utility involved is certain(profit) rather than have a probabilistic guess , it should 

be safe to follows the well established mechanisms rather than follow natural tendencies.

history.subject: Bounded Rationality limited intelligent assumptions
history.content:
Till now we have considered rational and intelligent players, in real life these assumptions are too much to ask.Common folks many times struggle to remember, process, or interpret the signals or routine tasks seems more easier than to reason out every choice they make everyday. Can the results such as Bayesian Nash Equilibrium, all the different mechanisms be made more robust to work in such setting?
( This can be one for the reason I guess DSIC is more desirable than BIC while implementing any mechanism).

BIC is dependent on the priors,Changing the prior might alter the BIC . In DSIC this will not be a problem. DSIC is independent of priors hence DSIC is more desirable, If a mechanism is robust enough to capture all priors then Bayesian Nash equilibrium is more desirable.

child.subject: Changing the priors alter BIC, changing it slightly might give us very different answers than original one.We desire mechanisms which are epsilon insensitive to the change in priors I e slight changes in priors (players belief) do not change the equilibrium completely. This robustness can even define applicability of particular mechanism in real life.

history.subject: Minimum number of steps to guess an item in a database (from Math Stack Exchange)
history.content: Let's say I have a database of N*N size (N rows N columns). My friend wants me to guess the location of an item. We start by binary guess, means I ask him if it is in upper half, he says yes or no, if its in the upper half, then I ask if it is in left upper half or right upper half, he again answers me and so on What are the minimum number of guesses I have to make to guess the location correctly keeping in mind that HE IS ALLOWED TO LIE FOR TWO TIMES.

history.subject: The Game "31": What is the winning strategy? (from Math Stack Exchange)
history.content:
My Maths teacher taught us how to play a game called 31 on Friday. Not once did my Maths teacher lose. I want to know why.

I'll explain the game...

31 is a game between two people.

Let's say you've got a grid of numbers - 6 rows, 4 columns. Each column contains the numbers 1-6, such that the first row will contain only 1's, the second will contain only 2's and so on.

Player one begins by choosing an entry from the grid, crossing it off and recording the number chosen. Player two then chooses another entry from the grid (could be the same number), crosses it off and adds this to the number previously recorded. Once an entry has been crossed off, it cannot be reused. The objective is to make the total reach 31 on your turn.

I've established that if you make the total reach 24 on your turn, the next turn a number would have to be chosen which would not allow the total to exceed 30, and hence you would win on your next turn, providing that the entry required to reach 31 had not been crossed off. Furthermore, if you make the total reach 17 on your turn, the next turn a number would have to be chosen which would not allow the total to exceed 23, and hence you would reach 24 on your next turn, providing that the entry required to reach 24 had not been crossed off. Further "magic numbers" are hence 10 and 3.

Using this "magic number" logic, I decided to attempt to beat my Maths teacher. He still beat me - I reached 24 no problem, but ran out of entries in a row (sorry - cannot remember which, think it was row 3), and so, he was crowned the winner to yet another student.

What must be the winning strategy?
What are these magic numbers?

history.subject: Matchsticks Game (from Math Stack Exchange)
history.content:
There are N matchsticks at the table. Two players play the game. Rules: (i) A player in his or her turn can pick a or b match sticks. (ii) The player who picks the last matchstick loses the game.

  1. What should be the conditions on N so that a winning strategy can be derived for the first player?

  2. What should be the strategy of first player so that he or she always wins this game provided N is such that a winning strategy can be derived?

Are there two stacks of matchsticks with types a and b ...and how many matchsticks each player is allowed to pick? ?

the question sounds similar to the game Satyanath was demonstrating on csa open day.

child.subject: 1. It depends on who plays first not N.whichever player plays first will have a dominant strategy of winning this game

history.subject: Social Choice Function
history.content:
Consider a procurement auction for a single indivisible good with a buyer (agent 0) and n
suppliers (1, 2, . . . , n). Each supplier submits a sealed bid and whoever submits the smallest bid
will win the auction. If multiple players submit the same bid, then the agent with the lowest
index among them is announced as the winner. The winning agent will receive a sum equal to the
bid. Assume that the bids from the agents are independent draws from the uniform distribution
on [0,1]. For this scenario, under a quasi-linear setting, write down the social choice function
being implemented. Is the social choice function ex-post efficient? What is the underlying
mechanism. Write down the components of the Bayesian game induced by this mechanism.

history.subject: Social Choice Function
history.content:
Consider a seller who is faced with a single buyer. The type set of the buyer is Θ = {0, 1, 2}.
The set of outcomes is X = {a, b, c}. The valuation function of the buyer is v(a, θ) = 0 ∀ θ ∈ Θ;
v(b, θ) = θ ∀ θ ∈ Θ; v(c, θ) = θ ∀ θ ∈ Θ. Write down all incentive compatible social choice
2
functions for this setting. Note that there is only one agent here.

There are 5 scf's according to me.

scf1 : f(0)=f(1)=f(2)= x

scf2 : f(0)=f(1)=f(2)= y

scf3 : f(0)=f(1)=f(2)= z

scf4: f(0) = x, f(1)= f(2)=y

scf5 :f(0) = x ,f(1)=f(2)= z

child.subject:
One more SCF is possible:

SCF6 : f(0) = y f(1) = f(2) = z
